com.newatlanta.commons.vfs.provider.gae
Class GaeVFS

java.lang.Object
  com.newatlanta.commons.vfs.provider.gae.GaeVFS

public class GaeVFS
extends java.lang.Object

This class is the entry point for interacting with the Google App Engine Virtual File System (GaeVFS). Its primary function is to create and initialize the GaeFileSystemManager static instance, which is done via the static getManager() method. Nearly all other interaction with GaeVFS is done via the Apache Commons VFS API.

IMPORTANT! The webapp root directory must be set via the setRootPath(String) method before invoking getManager() the first time.
IMPORTANT! The GaeVFS local file cache must be cleared at the end of every request via the clearFilesCache() method. See the GaeMemcacheFilesCache class for an explanation of why this is necessary.
IMPORTANT! Do not use the org.apache.commons.vfs.VFS.getManager() method provided by Commons VFS to get a FileSystemManager when running within GAE.

Author:
Vince Bonfanti

Method Detail

getManager

public static GaeFileSystemManager getManager()
                                       throws org.apache.commons.vfs.FileSystemException
Creates and initializes the GaeFileSystemManager static instance.
IMPORTANT! The webapp root directory must be set via the setRootPath(String) method before invoking getManager() the first time. This will normally be done within the servlet init() method:

public void init() throws ServletException {
    GaeVFS.setRootPath( getServletContext.getRealPath( "/" ) );
}
Failure to set the webapp root path properly will result in unexpected errors.

Returns:
The GaeFileSystemManager static instance.
Throws:
org.apache.commons.vfs.FileSystemException

setRootPath

public static void setRootPath(java.lang.String rootPath)
Sets the webapp root path for resolving file names.

File path URIs that do not start with "/" are interpreted as relative paths from the webapp root directory. Paths that start with "/" are interpreted (initially) as full absolute paths.

Absolute paths must specify sub-directories of the webapp root directory. Any absolute path that does not specify such a sub-directory is interpreted to be a relative path from the webapp root directory, regardless of the fact that it starts with "/". IMPORTANT! The webapp root directory must be set via the setRootPath(String) method before invoking getManager() the first time. This will normally be done within the servlet init() method:

public void init() throws ServletException {
    GaeVFS.setRootPath( getServletContext.getRealPath( "/" ) );
} Failure to set the webapp root path properly will result in unexpected errors.

Parameters:
rootPath - The webapp root path.

getBlockSize

public static int getBlockSize()
Gets the current default block size used when creating new files.

Returns:
The current default block size as an absolute number of bytes.

setBlockSize

public void setBlockSize(int size)
Sets the default block size used when creating new files. GaeVFS stores files as a series of blocks. Each block corresponds to a Google App Engine datastore entity and therefore has a maximum size of 1 megabyte (due to entity overhead, the actual limit is 1023 * 1024 = 1,047,552 bytes). The default block size is 128KB (131,072 bytes).

Parameters:
size - The default block size in units of K (1024) bytes. The minimum size is 1 and the maximum size is 1023.

setBlockSize

public static org.apache.commons.vfs.FileObject setBlockSize(org.apache.commons.vfs.FileObject fileObject,
                                                             int size)
                                                      throws org.apache.commons.vfs.FileSystemException
Sets the block size for the specified file. GaeVFS stores files as a series of blocks. Each block corresponds to a Google App Engine datastore entity and therefore has a maximum size of 1 megabyte (due to entity overhead, the actual limit is 1023 * 1024 = 1,047,552 bytes). The default block size is 128KB (131,072 bytes).

Parameters:
fileObject - The file for which the block size is to be set. The file must not exist; if it does, a FileSystemException is thrown.
size - The block size in units of K (1024) bytes. The minimum size is 1 and the maximum size is 1023.
Returns:
The fileObject for which the block size was set, to support method chaining.
Throws:
org.apache.commons.vfs.FileSystemException

resolveFile

public static org.apache.commons.vfs.FileObject resolveFile(java.lang.String name)
                                                     throws org.apache.commons.vfs.FileSystemException
Locates a file by name. A convenience method equivalent to GaeVFS.getManager().resolveFile(name). The file name URI format supported by GaeVFS is:
gae://path
where path is a UNIX-style (or URI-style) absolute or relative path. Paths that do not start with "/" are interpreted as relative paths from the webapp root directory. Paths that start with "/" are interpreted (initially) as full absolute paths.

Absolute paths must specify sub-directories of the webapp root directory. Any absolute path that does not specify such a sub-directory is interpreted to be a relative path from the webapp root directory, regardless of the fact that it starts with "/". It's probably easiest to just use relative paths and let GaeVFS handle the path translations transparently. The exception might be in cases where you're writing portable code to run in both GAE and non-GAE environments.

Examples:

gae://myfile.zip
gae://images/picture.jpg
gae://docs/mydocument.pdf
NOTE: the Combined Local Option--which is enabled by default--allows you to access GaeVFS file system resources by specifying URIs that omit the gae:// scheme. See the GaeFileSystemManager for further information on enabling and disabling the GaeVFS Combined Local option.

Parameters:
name - The name of the file system resource (file or folder) to locate.
Returns:
The file system resource (file or folder).
Throws:
org.apache.commons.vfs.FileSystemException

clearFilesCache

public static void clearFilesCache()
Clears the GaeVFS local file cache by invoking GaeFileSystemManager.clearFilesCache(). It's very important that the GaeVFS local file cache is cleared at the end of every servlet request via the clearFilesCache() method, best placed within a finally clause; for example:
public void doGet( HttpServletRequest req, HttpServletResponse res )
        throws ServletException, IOException {
    try {
        // ...process the GET request...
    } finally {
        GaeVFS.clearFilesCache(); // this is important!
    }
}
See the GaeMemcacheFilesCache class for an explanation of why this is necessary.

close

public static void close()
Releases all resources used by GaeVFS. It's good practice, but not strictly necessary, to close GaeVFS when your servlet is destroyed to aid in clean-up of GaeVFS resources:
public void destroy() {
    GaeVFS.close(); // this is not strictly required, but good practice
}
